results.headline: Review: A Long-Buried Family Secret Explodes in ‘The Daughter’
results.summary_short: This drama, set in a declining Australian logging town, centers on an estranged son who comes home, smoldering with resentment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Daughter

results.headline: Review: ‘Paris 05:59 Théo & Hugo’ Finds Two Men Out to Get Lucky
results.summary_short: The movie features its title characters meeting in a sex club, then venturing out into the Paris night for a more intimate assessment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paris 05:59 Théo & Hugo

results.headline: Review: Alice Returns in ‘Resident Evil: The Final Chapter’
results.summary_short: In the sixth entry in Paul W. S. Anderson’s dystopian franchise, Milla Jovovich’s character is back in zombie land, aided by her former nemesis the Red Queen.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Resident Evil: The Final Chapter

results.headline: Review: ‘S Is for Stanley,’ on Stanley Kubrick’s Longtime Driver
results.summary_short: This documentary focuses on Emilio D’Alessandro, who spent 30 years as an assistant and friend to the acclaimed film director.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of S Is for Stanley

results.headline: Review: Climate Change and Conflicts in ‘The Age of Consequences’
results.summary_short: Jared P. Scott’s film explores the issue from the perspective of military experts rather than that of scientists. The information is compelling, but the movie is ham-handed.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Age of Consequences

results.headline: Review: ‘I Am Michael’ Portrays a Gay Activist Seeking to Be Straight
results.summary_short: In the dreary purgatory projected by Justin Kelly’s film, James Franco stars as a man who claims no longer to be gay and becomes a Christian pastor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Am Michael

results.headline: Review: ‘Kung Fu Yoga’ Features Jackie Chan Saving the Day
results.summary_short: Mr. Chan mugs and thwarts assailants in this harmless international romp.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kung Fu Yoga

results.headline: Review: ‘Lost in Florence’ Blends Romantic Fantasy and a Rough Sport
results.summary_short: Evan Oppenheimer’s film is a mild romantic drama with a guy perspective, featuring beautiful women and a brutal athletic spectacle.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lost in Florence

results.headline: Review: ‘Midsummer in Newtown’ Revisits the Pain of Sandy Hook
results.summary_short: This documentary explores the value of a Shakespeare production intended to help residents heal after the horrific school shooting.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Midsummer in Newtown

results.headline: Review: Matthew McConaughey Mines Profane Capitalism in ‘Gold’
results.summary_short: He plays a rogue who strikes it rich, a thrill complicated by the corruptions of wealth, treachery and the schemer’s own fecklessness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gold

results.headline: Review: ‘A Dog’s Purpose,’ With Many Lives and Many Clichés
results.summary_short: This film, opening amid a call for a PETA boycott, is a string of hero-dog fantasies and observations from the canine point of view.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Dog’s Purpose

results.headline: Review: ‘Saving Banksy’ Affirms Graffiti’s Populist Values
results.summary_short: This documentary honors the street-based work of the British artist known as Banksy, and implicitly criticizes those who would try to turn profits from it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saving Banksy

results.headline: Review: M. Night Shyamalan’s ‘Split’ Has Personality. O.K., Personalities. Lots.
results.summary_short: “Split” represents something of a return to form — or formula — for its writer and director, M. Night Shyamalan. It’s all plot, spun into a ribbon of suspense.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Split

results.headline: Review: ‘The Red Turtle,’ Life Marooned With an Ornery Reptile
results.summary_short: This largely nonverbal animated French-Belgian-Japanese coproduction, from Studio Ghibli, the home of Hayao Miyazaki, flirts with eco-mysticism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Red Turtle

results.headline: Review: The French Countryside Holds Surprises in ‘Staying Vertical’
results.summary_short: In Alain Guiraudie’s quirky hybrid of thriller, sex comedy and folk tale, a screenwriter meets a shepherdess and, voilà, a baby is born.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Staying Vertical

results.headline: Review: Turning the World On, the LSD Way, in ‘The Sunshine Makers’
results.summary_short: Cosmo Feilding Mellen’s documentary suggests that two young men saw themselves as spreading transcendence one hit at a time.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sunshine Makers

results.headline: Review: In ‘Trespass Against Us,’ a Thieving Clan and a Yearning to Escape
results.summary_short: Michael Fassbender and Brendan Gleeson star in Adam Smith’s first feature, which has a mutinous energy and an absurd, knockabout charm.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trespass Against Us

results.headline: Review: ‘XXX: Return of Xander Cage’ Deploys Vin Diesel on a New Mission
results.summary_short: In the third installment of this franchise, the hero and new oddball allies set out to retrieve a stolen superweapon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of XXX: Return of Xander Cage

results.headline: Review: Cannibalism, Torture and Apocalypse in ‘We Are the Flesh’
results.summary_short: This debut feature by the Mexican writer and director Emiliano Rocha Minter seems to build on the character of Coffin Joe in the 1960s films by José Mojica Marins.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are the Flesh

results.headline: Review: ‘They Call Us Monsters,’ but Do We Deserve Life Sentences?
results.summary_short: This documentary contains excerpts from a film made with the help of juveniles facing trial as adults, who are confronting the possibility of life in prison.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of They Call Us Monsters
